page.title: 16LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: Pelsall dates back to A.D. 994 where, in Wulfruns Charter it was recorded as Peolshale and belonged to the Canons of Wolverhampton. In the Domesday Book it is described as 'WASTE'. In 1311 reference is made to a church, a small place of worship in Paradise Lane.In 1327 the population consisted of only 11 men. By the end of the 19th century several hundred men were employed in Pelsall Ironworks When the iron trade slumped Pelsalls period of heavy industry ended. Modern day Pelsall is now a thriving village with a population of 12,000.It has come a long way since the 'Waste' land of the first Domesday Book.
